title: Woolworths underpaid staff up to $300m
text:
"The highest priority for Woolworths Group right now is to address this issue, and to ensure that it doesn’t happen again," he said.

Woolworths launched a review in February with the assistance of PwC when managers under annualised salaries started to question whether they had been paid correctly under the General Retail Industry Award.

The queries were triggered by the managers comparing their pay to Woolworths' new enterprise agreement which covers the bulk of its staff in supermarkets but not managers.

Annual salaries for store managers cover ordinary working hours and reasonable overtime.

But the managers are still to entitled to the award's minimum hourly rates, penalties and overtime pay if they work enough long hours, late nights or weekends that their salary doesn't cover their time worked.

The review found the number of hours worked, and when they were worked, were not adequately factored into the individual salary settings for some salaried store team members.

Annualised salaries behind big underpayments

The problem of underpaying annualised salary employees has been the primary cause behind a recent spate of high-profile multi-million dollar underpayments affecting big companies, including George Calombaris' Made Establishment, defence giant Thales and ABC.

Advertisement

However, with more than 100,000 staff, Woolworths' underpayments are by far the biggest underpayment on record and raise questions about how many other other large companies could be affected by the problem.

While awards generally require employers to ensure they do not underpay workers on annualised salaries they do not specifically require annual pay reconciliations matching their hours with their pay.

But from March next year, new rules will require companies to conduct regular pay reconciliations for annualised salaried employees under 19 industry awards, including administrative workers, graduate lawyers and paralegals and financial planners.

Workers in mining and hydrocarbons, manufacturing, telecommunications, health, restaurant and hospitality sectors are also affected.

FWO puts boards on notice

FWO Sandra Parker said she was frustrated at the upsurge of large-scale businesses admitting they did not classify staff correctly, pay overtime or penalty rates, or complete annual pay reconciliations where they are required.

“Lately, we are seeing a disturbing number of large corporates publicly admitting that they have underpaid their staff. Some of these matters go back many years and several comprise millions of dollars owed to workers. This is simply not good enough,” she said.

"Companies should expect that breaking workplace laws will end in a public court enforcement outcome."

Advertisement

She said the underpayments, which affected Qantas, ABC, Commonwealth Bank, Bunnings, Super Retail Group and Michael Hill Jewellers, were caused by "ineffective governance combined with complacency and carelessness toward employee entitlements" and warned that boards were now on notice.

“I intend to take this issue up with Boards around the country, because frankly that is the level within organisations that should be taking an active leadership role on this issue, and seeking assurance about compliance from executive managers.”

Woolworths said it was committed to fully rectifying the payment shortfalls and had put in place a plan to ensure salaried team members’ pay was correct and compliant moving forward.

Review extends to Big W, Endeavour Drinks

The supermarket giant estimates the total backpay, assuming the issue goes as far back as the start of the modern award in 2010, to be between $200 million and $300 million before tax.

Affected current and former salaried team members will receive their full entitlements, including back payments with interest and superannuation contributions, as soon as possible.

Interim back payments will be made before Christmas to salaried store team members for the two years reviewed to date (September 2017 to August 2019).

Each worker may have been underpaid as much as $5200 a year, based on the top end of the estimated range and stretching back to 2010.

Advertisement

The review is being extended to all Woolworths Group businesses in Australia, including Big W and Endeavour Drinks, to ensure that all relevant award requirements have been met for salaried staff.

Woolworths will provide an update at the half year results in February and is expected to book provisions for the under-payments at its full year results.
description: Australia's largest retailer will repay about 5700 salaried staff between $200 million and $300 million after finding they had been underpaid for several years.
